keyTakeAways: Afghanistan has withdrawn from an international T20 cricket series due to the killing of three local cricketers in an air strike attributed to Pakistan.
The victims were civilians who were eating after a local match, and the attack also killed eight others, raising serious human rights and humanitarian concerns.

The Pakistan government claims the strike targeted militants, denying civilian casualties, while Afghan officials and the ICC assert the attack targeted civilians and was a deliberate act of violence.
The ICC expressed deep sorrow and condemned the attack, affirming solidarity with the Afghan cricket board and highlighting the global significance of sports in peacebuilding.
A temporary truce between Afghanistan and Pakistan, which had been set to expire, has been extended to allow for peace talks in Doha, Qatar.
Afghanistan’s delegation has arrived in Doha for negotiations, with the Taliban government stating it will participate despite Pakistan’s actions.
Zimbabwe has been invited to replace Afghanistan in the cricket series, reflecting the immediate impact of the incident on international sports diplomacy.

The incident has intensified regional tensions, with both nations accusing each other of violence and aggression, and has drawn international attention to cross-border security and human rights issues.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan has withdrawn from an upcoming T20 cricket series following the tragic killing of three local cricketers—Kabeer Agha, Sibghatullah, and Haroon—in an air strike on the border with Pakistan. The attack, which also killed eight civilians, reportedly targeted a home in Urgon district, Paktika province, where the players were dining after a match. The Afghanistan Cricket Board (ACB) condemned the strike, attributing it to the Pakistani regime, while Pakistan denied targeting civilians, claiming it was a military operation against militants. The International Cricket Council (ICC) expressed deep sorrow and condemned the violence, standing in solidarity with Afghanistan. The incident occurred amid a fragile 48-hour truce between the two nations, which has since been extended to allow peace talks in Doha, Qatar. The Taliban government affirmed its participation in negotiations despite accusing Pakistan of aggression. In response to the tragedy, Zimbabwe has been invited to replace Afghanistan in the cricket series, illustrating how a regional security crisis directly impacts international sports diplomacy.
title: Afghanistan pulls out of cricket series after it says Pakistan air strike killed local players
